entry.et: Middle English carre, from Anglo-French, from Latin carra, plural of carrum, alteration of carrus, of Celtic origin; akin to Old Irish & Middle Welsh carr vehicle; akin to Latin currere to run

def.dt: :a vehicle designed to move on rails (as of a railroad)
:the part of an airship or balloon that carries the passengers and cargo
:an explosive device concealed in an automobile for use as a weapon of terrorism
:an arrangement in which a group of people commute together by car
:the group entering into such an arrangement
:a portable seat for an infant or a small child that attaches to an automobile seat and holds the child safely
:an area or structure equipped with facilities for washing automobiles
:a small electric car made to be driven around in an enclosure and to be bumped into others (as at an amusement park)
